articles.title: World Entrepreneurs and Investment Forum puts women at the heart of economic transformation
articles.summary: Women entrepreneurs must be recognized as the architects of economic change and not the beneficiaries.
articles.content:
That was the central message of the Manama Declaration, issued at the close of the World Entrepreneurs and Investment Forum (WEIF) held this week in Bahrain.

The declaration places women at the heart of economic transformation, underscoring that empowering them within business and innovation ecosystems is essential to achieving inclusive and sustainable growth.

It also calls for strengthening women’s presence across emerging sectors, including the green, blue and orange economies which respectively promote environmental responsibility, sustainable use of ocean resources and creativity.

Organized by the UN Industrial Development Organization’s (UNIDO) Investment and Technology Promotion Office in Bahrain, the forum convened leaders, investors and entrepreneurs from around the world to shape a more resilient global economy and unlock new opportunities for women-led enterprises.

Abdelmonem Makki Women entrepreneurs gather on stage at the International Woman Entrepreneurial Challenge 2026 in Manama, Bahrain.

“An amazing opportunity”

For many participants, the forum delivered tangible results.

Doris Martin, CEO of DMartin Consultancy in Bahrain, attended in search of meaningful collaboration and found it.

Through business-to-business (B2B) meetings facilitated during the event, she established partnerships with companies in the United Arab Emirates and Morocco.

“This forum has been effective for me,” she told UN News. “I’ve had B2B collaboration with regional companies through Bahrain and through UNIDO.”

Tosin Arwejulo, CEO of Leadership Excel Consultancy and a Nigerian-American entrepreneur based in Bahrain, described the forum as a “powerful networking platform.”

“I’ve had the opportunity to talk to people from literally every continent,” she said. “It has been an amazing opportunity to connect with like-minded leaders.”

UN News/Abdelmonem Makki From left to right: Tosin Arwejulo, CEO of Leadership Excel Consultancy and a Nigerian-American entrepreneur based in Bahrain, and Doris Martin, CEO of DMartin Consultancy in Bahrain(In the middle).

Shared challenges, shared solutions

The forum’s impact extended beyond the Arab region.

Ayanthi Gurusinghe, President of the Ceylon Chamber of Women Entrepreneurs in Sri Lanka and representative of the South Asian Women Development Forum, attended alongside delegates from India, Nepal, Bangladesh and Pakistan.

She said participants exchanged valuable lessons, particularly around access to finance, a challenge faced by women entrepreneurs across regions.

“It was a good opportunity for networking, to come together, share views, learn and exchange experiences,” she said, expressing appreciation to UNIDO for creating a space where global connections could flourish.

UN News/Abdelmonem Makki Ayanthi Gurusinghe, President of the Ceylon Chamber of Women Entrepreneurs in Sri Lanka and representative of the South Asian Women Development Forum, at WEIF 2026 in Bahrain.

Special focus on artists with disabilities

Beyond panel discussions and networking sessions, the forum also spotlighted inclusive entrepreneurship through three exhibitions including on “Determined Creative Entrepreneur.”

Among the exhibitors was Nisreen Samour of Micro Art Center in Bahrain, which specializes in training and developing artistic talent, with a special focus on artists with disabilities.

“Today, we have about nine students participating, each specializing in an artistic field that aligns with their interests and abilities,” she said.

“I personally train them, and we are currently working on developing their skills and empowering them to produce professional artwork that will help them effectively enter the art market and the job market, thus contributing to increased productivity and the center's overall performance” she told UN News.

The centre also works with orphans, helping them develop artistic skills and showcase their work publicly — fostering independence and self-reliance through creativity.

UN News/Abdelmonem Makki Nisreen Samour of Micro Art Center in Bahrain, which specializes in training and developing artistic talent, with a special focus on artists with disabilities.

The role of academia

One recurring theme was the role of higher education in preparing young women to enter the world of entrepreneurship.

In an interview with UN News, Dr. Nihal Al-Najjar, professor at the Royal University for Women in Bahrain, highlighted the need to embed entrepreneurship deeply within academic systems.

“Our academic role is to integrate entrepreneurship not just as a subject, but as a methodology,” she said, explaining that experiential learning and practical application are key. “We encourage students to think, innovate and identify gaps in society, and then work to find solutions.”

She added that universities must go beyond classroom teaching by connecting students to the wider entrepreneurial ecosystem, guiding them towards mentorship, funding opportunities and professional networks when they are ready to launch their own ventures.

UN News/Abdelmonem Makki Dina Najar at WEIF2026 in Manama, Bahrain, covering Sustainable Development Goals.

A driving force for sustainable development

The World Entrepreneurs and Investment Forum (WEIF) was preceded by the annual conference of the International Women Entrepreneurial Challenge (IWEC)—a New York-based NGO that helps women-owned businesses to grow.

Speaking at the conference, UNIDO Director General Gerd Müller described women’s entrepreneurship as a driving force for sustainable development, global innovation and economic inclusion.

“We must ensure that women everywhere have a level playing field and are given the opportunity to unlock their full potential,” he stated, highlighting persistent barriers to finance, technology, and higher-skilled roles for women globally.

Reaffirming UNIDO’s commitment, he added that “empowering women is essential to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals.” The 17 SDGs, adopted by governments in 2015, provide a blueprint for a more just and equitable future for all people and the planet.

Mr. Müller praised Bahrain’s leadership in supporting entrepreneurship and women’s economic participation and outlined UNIDO’s ongoing work in crisis-affected countries, noting, “UNIDO has just started working to set up recovery programmes in Syria, Sudan, and Palestine… mostly the women there are affected, and they need our support.”

UNIDO ITPO Bahrain Gerd Müller, Director General of UNIDO, speaking at the International Woman Entrepreneurial Conference in Bahrain 2026.

Women as engines of business

In her opening remarks, IWEC Chair Ibukun Awosika highlighted women’s transformative role as engines of business, leadership, and national progress.

She emphasized that women constitute half of the world’s productive assets and, when empowered, become game changers in corporate and political leadership. Drawing on her own journey, Ms. Awosika recalled building a manufacturing group over 36 years before becoming the first and only woman chair of sub-Saharan Africa’s oldest financial institution, First Bank of Nigeria.

“What women represent to the world is 50 per cent of its assets — productive, constructive assets that are game changers when fully deployed,” she said.

“Every nation that has enough wisdom to invest and to actualize the talent that is in 50 per cent of its population is a country that is set to win.”

UNIDO ITPO Bahrain H.E. Mrs. Ibukun Awo, IWECC Chair, speaking at WEIF2026 in Bahrain.

Success Stories from Bahrain and Nigeria

According to its website, the International Women Entrepreneurial Challenge (IWEC) has recognized 575 distinguished awardees globally, honoured annually at its conferences and nominated by partner organizations, representing women-owned businesses from across the world.

In Bahrain, IWEC recognized a new cohort of awardees from the Middle East and Africa.

Among them was Sonia Mohamed Janahi, founder of Maya La Chocolaterie, who highlighted UNIDO’s role in advancing women’s entrepreneurship.

With UNIDO’s support, Janahi expanded her Bahraini chocolate brand into Africa, establishing a cocoa processing plant in Côte d’Ivoire, creating jobs, promoting ethical supply chains, and ensuring global recognition for African-produced chocolate.

Abdelmonem Makki Official event photo from WEIF2026 in Manama, Bahrain.

“UNIDO has played a very vital role in my progression. They have taken my project and opened opportunities for me,” she told UN News, underscoring UNIDO’s commitment to recognizing women entrepreneurs across Bahrain, the Middle East, and Africa.

“This event represents women globally and investments over $6 billion that bring women globally together. It awards women who have not just started a business but have sustained a business and scaled up a business and have had an impact on the economy and on the society.”

Also honoured was Nigerian entrepreneur Oluwakelemi, who discussed her gifting and lifestyle retail business, which employs women and supports household incomes across Nigeria while preparing to expand internationally.

“I am passionate about building scalable African businesses with global reach,” she told UN News. “Not less than 5,000 people have been able to benefit from our business, from our work.”

articles.personality_title: Global forum highlights women as key drivers of economic change
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The World Entrepreneurs and Investment Forum (WEIF) took place in Bahrain, bringing together leaders, investors, and entrepreneurs from around the world. The event focused on supporting women entrepreneurs as central to economic growth and innovation.

**What happened** – At the forum’s close, the Manama Declaration was issued, emphasizing the importance of empowering women in business and emerging industries like green energy and creative sectors. The forum also featured networking opportunities, exhibitions supporting artists with disabilities, and discussions on how universities can better prepare young women for entrepreneurship.

**Impact** – The forum helped women entrepreneurs form new international partnerships, shared solutions to common challenges like access to finance, and highlighted inclusive efforts such as training artists with disabilities. It showed how women’s leadership can boost not only individual businesses but also broader economic development and sustainability goals.

**What’s next step** – Organizers and participants aim to continue expanding support for women-led businesses, including through education, mentorship, and investment. UNIDO plans to extend recovery programs to crisis-affected countries, focusing on helping women entrepreneurs rebuild and grow.

articles.personality_title_fr: Le forum mondial place les femmes au cœur du changement économique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le Forum mondial des entrepreneurs et de l’investissement (WEIF) s’est tenu à Bahreïn, réunissant des leaders, investisseurs et entrepreneurs du monde entier. L’événement a mis l’accent sur le soutien aux femmes entrepreneures comme moteur essentiel de la croissance économique et de l’innovation.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – À la clôture du forum, la Déclaration de Manama a été publiée, soulignant l’importance d’autonomiser les femmes dans les affaires et les secteurs émergents comme l’énergie verte et les industries créatives. Le forum a également offert des opportunités de réseautage, des expositions en faveur des artistes en situation de handicap, et des discussions sur la préparation des jeunes femmes à l’entrepreneuriat par l’éducation.

**Impact** – Le forum a permis aux femmes entrepreneures de créer de nouveaux partenariats internationaux, d’échanger sur des défis communs comme l’accès au financement, et a mis en lumière des initiatives inclusives telles que la formation d’artistes handicapés. Il a démontré que le leadership féminin renforce non seulement les entreprises individuelles, mais aussi le développement économique et les objectifs de durabilité.

**Prochaine étape** – Les organisateurs et participants souhaitent poursuivre le soutien aux entreprises dirigées par des femmes, notamment par l’éducation, le mentorat et l’investissement. L’ONUDI prévoit d’étendre ses programmes de relèvement dans les pays en crise, en se concentrant sur l’aide aux femmes entrepreneures pour reconstruire et se développer.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le WEIF à Bahreïn a montré que l’autonomisation des femmes entrepreneures dans le monde renforce les économies et ouvre de nouvelles opportunités d’innovation et d’inclusion.
articles.personality_title_es: Foro mundial destaca a las mujeres como motor clave del cambio económico
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El Foro Mundial de Emprendedores e Inversiones (WEIF) se celebró en Baréin, reuniendo a líderes, inversores y emprendedores de todo el mundo. El evento se centró en apoyar a las mujeres emprendedoras como pieza clave para el crecimiento económico y la innovación.

**Qué pasó** – Al cierre del foro, se emitió la Declaración de Manama, que subraya la importancia de empoderar a las mujeres en los negocios y en sectores emergentes como la energía verde y las industrias creativas. El foro también incluyó oportunidades de networking, exposiciones para artistas con discapacidades y discusiones sobre cómo las universidades pueden preparar mejor a las jóvenes para el emprendimiento.

**Impacto** – El foro ayudó a las mujeres emprendedoras a formar nuevas alianzas internacionales, compartir soluciones a desafíos comunes como el acceso a financiamiento, y destacó esfuerzos inclusivos como la capacitación de artistas con discapacidades. Mostró cómo el liderazgo femenino puede impulsar no solo negocios individuales, sino también el desarrollo económico y los objetivos de sostenibilidad.

**Próximo paso** – Los organizadores y participantes planean continuar ampliando el apoyo a negocios liderados por mujeres, incluyendo educación, mentoría e inversión. La UNIDO planea extender programas de recuperación en países afectados por crisis, enfocándose en ayudar a las mujeres emprendedoras a reconstruir y crecer.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El WEIF en Baréin demostró que empoderar a las mujeres emprendedoras en todo el mundo fortalece las economías y abre nuevas oportunidades para la innovación y la inclusión.

articles.title: Guterres tells AU Summit: ‘This is 2026 – not 1946’ in push for reform
articles.summary: Calling for sweeping reforms of global institutions, UN Secretary-General António Guterres told African leaders on Saturday that the absence of permanent African seats on the Security Council is “indefensible,” declaring: “This is 2026 – not 1946.”
articles.content:
In a world marked by division and mistrust, he said, the African Union (AU) stands as a “flagship for multilateralism,” as he addressed the 39th African Union Summit in Addis Ababa.

Mr. Guterres praised Africa’s global leadership in “the struggle for justice and equality,” noting that the UN-AU partnership is stronger than ever, built on “respect, constant dialogue and unwavering solidarity.”

Cooperation has reached “new heights” over the past decade, he added, pointing to joint frameworks on peace and security, sustainable development and human rights.

Tweet URL

Peace in Africa

The Secretary-General outlined three priorities for deeper cooperation: peace, economic action and climate justice.

On peace, he called for an immediate cessation of hostilities in Sudan, renewed dialogue in South Sudan, and respect for the territorial integrity of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Across the Sahel, Libya and the Horn of Africa, he stressed the need for African-led political solutions backed by sustained international support.

Economic action

Mr. Guterres further warned that developing countries face a $4 trillion annual Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) financing gap, while Africa loses more to debt servicing and illicit financial flows than it receives in aid.

At a press conference following the summit, he said it is “simply unconscionable” that Africa must contend with “an economic and financial system that remains totally unjust.”

He called for tripling the lending capacity of multilateral development banks and ensuring developing countries have “a real voice and a meaningful participation” in international financial institutions.

No more plundering

He also stressed that African countries must benefit directly from their natural wealth: “No more exploitation. No more plundering. The people of Africa must benefit from the resources of Africa.”

He urged that African countries benefit “first and fully from their critical minerals through fair, sustainable value chains and manufacturing,” in line with UN recommendations.

Climate justice

On climate, Mr. Guterres warned that “the science is unequivocal – the planet will overshoot the 1.5 degree Celsius limit.” The 1.5°C threshold, enshrined in the Paris Agreement, is considered critical to avoiding the most catastrophic and irreversible climate impacts.

“Africa did not cause the climate crisis,” he said, yet it faces faster-than-average warming, droughts, floods and deadly heat – “climate injustice – plain and simple.”

He called on developed countries to triple adaptation finance, mobilize $1.3 trillion annually for developing countries by 2035, and scale up the Loss and Damage Fund.

Reforms now

Mr. Guterres also underscored the urgent need for reforming global institutions.

The absence of permanent African seats on the Council is “indefensible; this is 2026 – not 1946,” he said, adding: “Whenever decisions about Africa and the world are on the table, Africa must be at the table.”
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories
articles.reasoning: The article highlights UN Secretary-General António Guterres' call for urgent reforms in global institutions to ensure African representation and justice, emphasizing peace, economic fairness, and climate justice. It reflects a significant push for equality, inclusion, and sustainable development with broad implications for Africa and the global community, providing a hopeful and inspiring message about advancing human rights and international cooperation.
articles.personality_title: UN chief urges urgent reforms for Africa’s role in global decisions
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres spoke at the 39th African Union Summit in Addis Ababa, where leaders gathered to discuss Africa’s future and its place in global affairs.

**What happened** – On June 10, 2023, Guterres called for major changes in how global institutions work. He said it is unfair that Africa does not have permanent seats on the UN Security Council, stating, “This is 2026 – not 1946.” He praised the African Union for leading efforts in peace, justice, and cooperation with the UN. Guterres highlighted three main areas for stronger partnership: peace, economic fairness, and climate justice.

**Impact** – This message is important because it pushes for Africa to have a stronger voice in world decisions that affect its people. Guterres emphasized stopping conflicts in places like Sudan and South Sudan, improving economic support by closing a $4 trillion funding gap for development, and addressing climate change impacts that hit Africa hardest, even though the continent contributed least to the problem. His speech signals a call for fairness and respect for Africa’s rights and resources.

**What’s next step** – The African Union and the UN will likely work together to push for changes in international organizations, including increasing Africa’s representation in decision-making bodies. There will also be efforts to improve peace talks and economic support, and to increase funding to help Africa adapt to climate change.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN Secretary-General’s call for reform highlights the need for Africa to have a stronger, fairer role in global peace, economy, and climate decisions.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le chef de l’ONU appelle à des réformes urgentes pour le rôle de l’Afrique dans les décisions mondiales
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le Secrétaire général des Nations Unies, António Guterres, s’est exprimé lors du 39e Sommet de l’Union africaine à Addis-Abeba, où les dirigeants se sont réunis pour discuter de l’avenir de l’Afrique et de sa place dans les affaires mondiales.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 10 juin 2023, Guterres a demandé des changements majeurs dans le fonctionnement des institutions mondiales. Il a déclaré qu’il est injuste que l’Afrique ne dispose pas de sièges permanents au Conseil de sécurité de l’ONU, affirmant : « Nous sommes en 2026 – pas en 1946. » Il a salué l’Union africaine pour son leadership dans la paix, la justice et la coopération avec l’ONU. Guterres a mis en avant trois domaines principaux pour un partenariat renforcé : la paix, l’équité économique et la justice climatique.

**Impact** – Ce message est important car il demande que l’Afrique ait une voix plus forte dans les décisions mondiales qui affectent ses populations. Guterres a souligné la nécessité de mettre fin aux conflits au Soudan et au Soudan du Sud, d’améliorer le soutien économique en comblant un déficit de financement de 4 000 milliards de dollars pour le développement, et de faire face aux impacts du changement climatique qui touchent l’Afrique de façon disproportionnée, alors que le continent est le moins responsable. Son discours appelle à la justice et au respect des droits et ressources de l’Afrique.

**Prochaines étapes** – L’Union africaine et l’ONU vont probablement collaborer pour promouvoir des changements dans les organisations internationales, notamment pour augmenter la représentation de l’Afrique dans les instances décisionnelles. Des efforts seront également faits pour améliorer les négociations de paix, le soutien économique et accroître les financements pour aider l’Afrique à s’adapter au changement climatique.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – L’appel du Secrétaire général de l’ONU souligne la nécessité pour l’Afrique d’avoir un rôle plus fort et plus juste dans les décisions mondiales sur la paix, l’économie et le climat.
articles.personality_title_es: El jefe de la ONU pide reformas urgentes para el papel de África en las decisiones globales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El Secretario General de la ONU, António Guterres, habló en la 39ª Cumbre de la Unión Africana en Addis Abeba, donde los líderes se reunieron para hablar sobre el futuro de África y su lugar en los asuntos mundiales.

**Qué pasó** – El 10 de junio de 2023, Guterres pidió cambios importantes en cómo funcionan las instituciones globales. Dijo que es injusto que África no tenga asientos permanentes en el Consejo de Seguridad de la ONU, afirmando: «Esto es 2026, no 1946.» Elogió a la Unión Africana por liderar esfuerzos en paz, justicia y cooperación con la ONU. Guterres destacó tres áreas principales para una asociación más fuerte: paz, justicia económica y justicia climática.

**Impacto** – Este mensaje es importante porque impulsa que África tenga una voz más fuerte en las decisiones mundiales que afectan a su gente. Guterres enfatizó la necesidad de detener conflictos en lugares como Sudán y Sudán del Sur, mejorar el apoyo económico cerrando una brecha de financiamiento de 4 billones de dólares para el desarrollo, y enfrentar los impactos del cambio climático que afectan más a África, aunque el continente haya contribuido menos al problema. Su discurso señala un llamado a la justicia y respeto por los derechos y recursos de África.

**Próximos pasos** – La Unión Africana y la ONU probablemente trabajarán juntos para promover cambios en las organizaciones internacionales, incluyendo aumentar la representación de África en los órganos de decisión. También habrá esfuerzos para mejorar las conversaciones de paz y el apoyo económico, y para aumentar la financiación para ayudar a África a adaptarse al cambio climático.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El llamado del Secretario General de la ONU destaca la necesidad de que África tenga un papel más fuerte y justo en las decisiones globales sobre paz, economía y clima.
